proof:
Every vertex $v$ in the set $A$ must belong to either $G_{Base}(k + 1)$ or to some set $P$ within a partition $\mathcal{P}_i$ for some player $i \in [k]$. Let us define $L_i$ as the union of all sets in the partition $\mathcal{P}_i$, so that $L_i := \cup_{P \in \mathcal{P}_i} P$. Given the constraint $n_k < \frac{3n}{\Delta^2}$, it follows that the number of vertices from $A$ that are also contained in the union $L_1 \cup \dots \cup L_k$ must be greater than $\frac{n(96\ell^2 \ln(n)+30)}{\Delta^2}$. By an application of the Pigeonhole principle, there must be a specific index $i \in [k]$ for which the intersection $L_i \cap A$ contains more than $\frac{n(96\ell^2 \ln(n)+30)}{\Delta^2}$ vertices. Since $\mathcal{P}_i$ is a partition of the vertices in $L_i$ and Lemma 4.4 provides the bound $|\mathcal{P}_i| \le \frac{3n}{\Delta^2}$, a second application of the Pigeonhole principle guarantees the existence of a particular set $P = (V_P, E_P) \in \mathcal{P}_i$ such that its intersection with $A$ has a size satisfying $|P \cap A| > 32\ell^2 \ln(n) + 10$.

Based on Lemma 3.4 and Lemma 3.5, the size of the largest possible clique in the graph $(H_{Miss}(M_i) - R_{i+1})[P]$ is at most
$$16\ln(n) \cdot \frac{d_{filter}}{d_{removal}} + 10 = 16 \cdot \frac{\ell^2\Delta}{\Delta/2} \cdot \ln(n) + 10 = 32\ell^2 \ln(n) + 10.$$
The size of the set $P \cap A$ is greater than this upper bound. Consequently, there must exist a pair of vertices $u, v \in P \cap A$ that are not connected by an edge in the graph $H_{Miss}(M_i) - R_{i+1}$.

If the edge $(u, v)$ is in $R_{i+1}$, we can use the original graph and edge assignments. We note that $R_{k+1} = \emptyset$ because $n_k < \frac{n}{\Delta^2}$, which ensures that Player $i+1$ exists and receives the set $R_{i+1}$. In this situation, an edge exists between $(u, v)$ in $G_{input}$.
Alternatively, if $(u, v) \notin R_{i+1}$, we can show that there is an index $j \in [i]$ for which $(u, v) \in H_{Base}(j)$ but $(u, v) \notin H_{Miss}(M_j)$. This is proven by considering two cases.

First, if $(u, v) \in G_{Base}(i)$, we can choose $j = i$. The equality $H_{Base}(i)[P] = G_{Base}(i)[P]$ implies that $(u, v) \in H_{Base}(i)$. Moreover, because we are in the case where $(u, v) \notin R_{i+1}$, it follows that $(u, v) \notin H_{Miss}(M_j)$ as well.

Second, if $(u, v) \notin G_{Base}(i)$, we use the fact that the graphs are nested, $G_{Base}(i) \subseteq \dots \subseteq G_{Base}(1)$, and that $(u, v) \in G_{Base}(1)$. This allows us to find an index $j < i$ where $(u, v) \in G_{Base}(j)$ but $(u, v) \notin G_{Base}(j+1)$. More precisely,
$$(u, v) \notin G_{Base}(j+1) = (G_{Base}(j) - (H_{Base}(j) - H_{Miss}(M_j)))[Q_j].$$
Since the vertices $u, v$ are in $G_{Base}(i)$ and all vertices of $G_{Base}(i)$ are also in $Q_j$, we know that $u, v \in Q_j$. From this, we can conclude that
$$(u, v) \notin G_{Base}(j) - (H_{Base}(j) - H_{Miss}(M_j)).$$
Given that we know $(u, v) \in G_{Base}(j)$, it must be that $(u, v)$ is in the set of removed edges, so $(u, v) \in H_{Base}(j) - H_{Miss}(M_j)$. This means that $(u, v) \in H_{Base}(j)$ and $(u, v) \notin H_{Miss}(M_j)$.

Since we have found a $j$ such that $(u, v) \in H_{Base}(j)$ and $(u, v) \notin H_{Miss}(M_j)$, the definition of $H_{Miss}$ implies the existence of another graph $H' \in \mathcal{H}_j$ where $(u, v)$ is an edge and $\Phi_j(H') = M_j$. We can then modify the construction by substituting $H_j$ with this $H'$ to define a new input graph $G'_{input}$ and a new set of edges to send to the players. With this change, every player still sends the same message, but now the edge $(u, v)$ is present in $G'_{input}$, which completes the proof.
